Das funktioniert nicht mit einem HuggingFace-Tokenizer wie T5Tokenizer, da T5Tokenizer kein texts_to_sequences() kennt. Diese Methode stammt aus dem alten keras.preprocessing.text.Tokenizer.

Außerdem übergibst du test_seq danach an decode_sequence(), obwohl decode_sequence() eigentlich erwartet, dass du den input_text (als String) übergibst – nicht ein gepaddetes Sequence-Array.

🔧 So behebst du es:

Ersetze diese Zeilen:

python
test_seq = tokenizer.texts_to_sequences(test_text)
test_seq = pad_sequences(test_seq, maxlen=model.input_shape[0][1], padding='post')
summary = decode_sequence(test_seq)

durch einfach:

python
summary = decode_sequence(test_text[0])

✅ Alternativ: Passe decode_sequence an

Falls du decode_sequence lieber mit Encodings aufrufen willst (anstatt mit dem Text direkt), dann musst du dort die Tokenizer-Verarbeitung auslagern.

⚠️ Weiterer Hinweis:

In deinem decoder_model fehlt ein wichtiger Input: decoder_hidden_state_input, das die Encoder-Ausgabe für die Attention-Schicht liefert. Das wird in der attention_layer verwendet, aber im Modell nicht als Input deklariert. Das wird bei Inferenz zu einem Fehler führen, etwa so:

You are passing a KerasTensor to a layer that was not built to receive it

Du solltest das Modell so definieren:

python
decoder_model = keras.Model(
    [decoder_inputs, decoder_hidden_state_input] + decoder_states_inputs,
    [decoder_outputs] + decoder_states,
    name="decoder_model"
)

Und bei decode_sequence() entsprechend aufrufen:

python
output_tokens, h, c = decoder_model.predict([target_seq, encoder_outputs] + states_value)

Dazu musst du auch encoder_model ändern, damit er encoder_outputs zusätzlich zurückgibt:

python
encoder_model = keras.Model(encoder_inputs, [encoder_outputs, state_h_enc, state_c_enc])

Dann in decode_sequence():

python
encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = encoder_model.predict(input_ids)
states_value = [state_h, state_c]

🧠 Zusammenfassung der Änderungen

  1. texts_to_sequences() entfernen – du verwendest T5Tokenizer.

  2. decode_sequence(test_text[0]) direkt mit String aufrufen.

  3. decoder_model um decoder_hidden_state_input erweitern.

  4. encoder_model um encoder_outputs erweitern.

  5. In decode_sequence encoder_outputs an decoder_model weitergeben.

Möchtest du, dass ich dir die korrigierten Codeabschnitte fertig mache?

Du:
import keras import numpy as np from keras.preprocessing.text import Tokenizer from keras import Input, Model, layers from datasets import load_dataset import tensorflow as tf from keras_preprocessing.sequence import pad_sequences import pickle from transformers import T5Tokenizer from keras.layers import Attention, Concatenate dataset = load_dataset("abisee/cnn_dailymail", "3.0.0") # # input_text = [ # "Angela Merkel wurde 2011 Bundeskanzlerin, nachdem sie die Wahl gewonnen hatte", # "Bayer hat vorgestern am Abend 5:3 gegen Dortmund gewonnen, war super das Spiel", # "Die deutsche Wirtschaft wächst trotz der internationalen Unsicherheiten stetig weiter.", # "Tesla hat kürzlich sein neues Elektroauto-Modell vorgestellt, das eine Reichweite von über 600 Kilometern bietet." # ] # # target_text = [ # "Angela Merkel wurde 2011 Bundeskanzlerin", # "Bayern gewann 5:3 gegen Dortmund", # "Deutsche Wirtschaft wächst trotz Unsicherheiten", # "Tesla stellt neues Elektroauto vor" # ] input_text = dataset['train']['article'][:10000] # Artikel aus dem Datensatz target_text = dataset['train']['highlights'][:10000] # #Tokenizer preparation # input_tokenizer = Tokenizer() # input_tokenizer.fit_on_texts(input_text) # formats the text into numbers like this TextVectorization # input_sequences = input_tokenizer.texts_to_sequences(input_text) # # start_token = '<start>' # end_token = '<end>' # target_text_with_tokens = [start_token + " " + text + " " + end_token for text in target_text] # OWN TOKENIZER # # target_tokenizer = Tokenizer(filters='',num_words=20000) # target_tokenizer.fit_on_texts(target_text_with_tokens) # target_sequences = target_tokenizer.texts_to_sequences(target_text_with_tokens) tokenizer = T5Tokenizer.from_pretrained("t5-small") input_encodings = tokenizer(input_text, padding="longest", truncation=True, return_tensors="np") target_encodings = tokenizer(target_text, padding="longest", truncation=True, return_tensors="np") encoder_input_data = input_encodings["input_ids"] decoder_input_data = target_encodings["input_ids"] vocab_size = tokenizer.vocab_size def trainTextSummarizer(): # Data preparation # max_encoder_seq_length = max(len(seq) for seq in input_sequences) # declares the max len for input and target # max_decoder_seq_length = max(len(seq) for seq in target_sequences) # # encoder_input_data = pad_sequences(input_sequences, maxlen=max_encoder_seq_length, # padding="post") # secures that all sequences have the same length if # # they are too short, # # padding is comming # decoder_input_data = pad_sequences(target_sequences, maxlen=max_decoder_seq_length, # padding="post") # parameter # num_encoder_tokens = len(input_tokenizer.word_index) + 1 # number of unique words plus 1 for the padding # num_decoder_tokens = len(target_tokenizer.word_index) + 1 # same here latent_dim = 128 # neuron count # encoder # encoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,)) # Input layer for the encoder with no declared shape # enc_emb = layers.Embedding(num_encoder_tokens, latent_dim)( # encoder_inputs) # changes every word from input to a vector with strict dimension the latent dimension (neurons) # # encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_state=True)(enc_emb) # encoder_states = [state_h, state_c] # brain status is returned, the most important features of the text # # # decoder # decoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,)) # Input layer for the decoder # dec_emb = layers.Embedding(num_decoder_tokens, latent_dim)( # decoder_inputs) # changes every word from input to a vector with strict dimension the latent dimension (neurons) # # decoder_outputs, _, _ =layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_sequences=True, return_state=True)(dec_emb, # initial_state=encoder_states) # brain status is returned (Not real) # decoder_outputs =layers.Dense(num_decoder_tokens, activation="softmax")(decoder_outputs) # # calculates the probability for each word in the target vocab from the output of the LSTM layer (softmax == all probability together equals 1 ) encoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,), name="encoder_inputs") enc_emb = layers.Embedding(input_dim=vocab_size, output_dim=latent_dim, name="encoder_embedding")( encoder_inputs) encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_sequences=True, return_state=True, name="encoder_lstm")(enc_emb) encoder_states = [state_h, state_c] decoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,), name="decoder_inputs") dec_emb = layers.Embedding(input_dim=vocab_size, output_dim=latent_dim, name="decoder_embedding")( decoder_inputs) decoder_lstm_outputs, _, _ = layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_sequences=True, return_state=True, name="decoder_lstm")(dec_emb, initial_state=encoder_states) # Attention Layer attention = layers.Attention(name="attention_layer")([decoder_lstm_outputs, encoder_outputs]) decoder_combined_context = layers.Concatenate(axis=-1)([decoder_lstm_outputs, attention]) # Output decoder_outputs = layers.Dense(vocab_size, activation="softmax", name="output_dense")(decoder_combined_context) model = Model([encoder_inputs, decoder_inputs], decoder_outputs) loss_fn = tf.keras.losses.SparseCategoricalCrossentropy(from_logits=False, reduction='none') def masked_loss(y_true, y_pred): loss = loss_fn(y_true, y_pred) mask = tf.cast(tf.not_equal(y_true, 0), dtype=loss.dtype) # 0 = <pad> return tf.reduce_mean(loss * mask) model.compile(optimizer='adam', loss=masked_loss, metrics=['accuracy']) model.summary() decoder_target_data = np.zeros_like(decoder_input_data) decoder_target_data[:, :-1] = decoder_input_data[:, 1:] model.fit([encoder_input_data, decoder_input_data], np.expand_dims(decoder_target_data, -1), batch_size=32, epochs=15) model.save("SummarizerModel.keras") # with open("input_tokenizer.pkl", "wb") as f: # pickle.dump(input_tokenizer, f) # with open("target_tokenizer.pkl", "wb") as f: # pickle.dump(target_tokenizer, f) # encoder takes the most important information out of the input text, the decoder gets this text and try's to build a new text concluding the important information # and all this is happening because the tokenizer makes the input to numbers and then via embedding vectors are generated in the encoder which are representing the state of the "brain" and # the decoder takes this and trys formating a new text # Vectors are essential because tokenizer don't learn with semantic but embeddings do, for words with same semantic they receive same vectors e.g. [0.3, 0,31] word 1 [0.32, 0.34] word 2 # each word is a vector as long as the latent dimension that why it's used in the embeddings # with tf.device('/GPU:0'): # /GPU:0 ist der Index für die erste GPU # trainTextSummarizer() model = keras.models.load_model("SummarizerModel.keras") # with open("input_tokenizer.pkl", "rb") as f: # input_tokenizer = pickle.load(f) # with open("target_tokenizer.pkl", "rb") as f: # target_tokenizer = pickle.load(f) # Encoder Model encoder_inputs = model.input[0] encoder_embedding = model.get_layer("encoder_embedding")(encoder_inputs) encoder_outputs, state_h_enc, state_c_enc = model.get_layer("encoder_lstm")(encoder_embedding) # LSTM Layers encoder_states = [state_h_enc, state_c_enc] encoder_model = keras.Model(encoder_inputs, [encoder_outputs, state_h_enc, state_c_enc]) # Decoder Model decoder_inputs = model.input[1] decoder_state_input_h = keras.Input(shape=(128,), name="decoder_state_input_h") decoder_state_input_c = keras.Input(shape=(128,), name="decoder_state_input_c") decoder_states_inputs = [decoder_state_input_h, decoder_state_input_c] decoder_hidden_state_input = Input(shape=(None, 128), name="decoder_hidden_input") dec_emb_layer = model.get_layer("decoder_embedding") dec_emb = dec_emb_layer(decoder_inputs) decoder_lstm = model.get_layer("decoder_lstm") decoder_lstm_outputs, state_h, state_c = decoder_lstm( dec_emb, initial_state=decoder_states_inputs ) attention_layer = model.get_layer("attention_layer") attention_output = attention_layer([decoder_lstm_outputs, decoder_hidden_state_input]) decoder_combined_context = Concatenate(axis=-1)([decoder_lstm_outputs, attention_output]) decoder_states = [state_h, state_c] decoder_dense = model.get_layer("output_dense") decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_combined_context) decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_outputs) decoder_model = keras.Model( [decoder_inputs,decoder_hidden_state_input] + decoder_states_inputs, [decoder_outputs] + decoder_states, name="decoder_model" ) # grabs from the pretrained model, the layers and build two new separate models # during inference they need to separately def decode_sequence(input_text): input_ids = tokenizer(input_text, return_tensors="np", padding="max_length", truncation=True, max_length=512)["input_ids"] encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = encoder_model.predict(input_ids) states_value = [state_h, state_c] target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1)) target_seq[0, 0] = tokenizer.convert_tokens_to_ids('<pad>') # oder <s> falls du das nutzt stop_condition = False decoded_sentence = "" while not stop_condition: output_tokens, h, c = decoder_model.predict([target_seq, encoder_outputs] + states_value) sampled_token_index = np.argmax(output_tokens[0, -1, :]) sampled_word = tokenizer.decode([sampled_token_index]) decoded_sentence += " " + sampled_word if sampled_word.strip() == "</s>" or len(decoded_sentence.split()) > 50: stop_condition = True target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1)) target_seq[0, 0] = sampled_token_index states_value = [h, c] return decoded_sentence.strip() test_text = ["Angela Merkel became Chancellor in 2011 after winning the election, just with 50% which is really crazy and cool"] summary = decode_sequence(test_text[0]) print(summary) so hier ?
ChatGPT:

The code you provided is for building a sequence-to-sequence model with attention for text summarization using Keras and TensorFlow. There are a few points of clarification and potential improvements that can be made:

  1. Model Loading:

    • The model is loaded using keras.models.load_model("SummarizerModel.keras") for inference.

    • This assumes that the model has already been trained and saved to the file "SummarizerModel.keras". However, you're skipping training the model and going directly to inference in the code block provided. Ensure that you've run the training function (trainTextSummarizer) at least once before running inference.

  2. Decoder Model:

    • In the part where you create the decoder_model, you should make sure that the input shapes for the decoder inputs match the shapes during inference. Specifically, the decoder_state_input_h, decoder_state_input_c, and decoder_hidden_state_input layers should have compatible dimensions with the training setup.

    • Also, decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_combined_context) is done twice. You should remove the second one.

  3. Tokenization for Inference:

    • In decode_sequence, the input text is tokenized using the T5 tokenizer. It's crucial to ensure that the tokenization and padding are applied correctly so that the sequences are aligned with what the model expects.

    • You used max_length=512, but the input size for your model might be different depending on how the padding is handled during training.

  4. Stop Condition in Inference Loop:

    • The stop condition is based on the word </s> (or <end>). You need to make sure that this token exists in the tokenizer's vocabulary, or it could break the inference process.

  5. Test Text:

    • You used the test sentence "Angela Merkel became Chancellor in 2011 after winning the election, just with 50% which is really crazy and cool". Ensure that this text is preprocessed similarly to how the model was trained (including padding and truncation).

Here’s a slightly modified version of your decode_sequence function with the issues mentioned above addressed:

python
def decode_sequence(input_text):
    # Tokenize input text and ensure padding/truncation to the correct sequence length
    input_ids = tokenizer(input_text, return_tensors="np", padding="max_length", truncation=True, max_length=512)["input_ids"]
    
    # Predict the encoder's output (states)
    encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = encoder_model.predict(input_ids)
    states_value = [state_h, state_c]
    
    # Initialize the target sequence with the <start> token (or padding token if applicable)
    target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1))
    target_seq[0, 0] = tokenizer.convert_tokens_to_ids('<pad>')  # Adjust if you use a different token like <s>
    
    stop_condition = False
    decoded_sentence = ""
    
    # Iterate through the sequence until stop condition is met
    while not stop_condition:
        output_tokens, h, c = decoder_model.predict([target_seq, encoder_outputs] + states_value)
        
        sampled_token_index = np.argmax(output_tokens[0, -1, :])  # Get the most probable next token
        sampled_word = tokenizer.decode([sampled_token_index])  # Decode the token index to a word
        
        decoded_sentence += " " + sampled_word  # Append the decoded word to the sentence

        # Stop if the end token is reached or if the sentence is too long
        if sampled_word.strip() == "</s>" or len(decoded_sentence.split()) > 50:
            stop_condition = True
        
        # Update the target sequence for the next step
        target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1))
        target_seq[0, 0] = sampled_token_index
        states_value = [h, c]  # Update states for the next prediction
    
    return decoded_sentence.strip()

Make sure that:

  • The tokenizer's special tokens like <pad>, <start>, and <end> match what you used during training.

  • You adjust max_length based on what the model was trained with (e.g., if it was trained on a smaller or larger input size).

  • If the model was trained on specific preprocessing like lowercase or other normalization steps, replicate those in the inference function.

Try running the model after making sure it has been trained.

Du:
also was muss ich ändern
ChatGPT:

In deinem Code gibt es einige Punkte, die du anpassen musst, um sicherzustellen, dass alles korrekt funktioniert, insbesondere im Hinblick auf das Modell und die Verwendung des Tokenizers. Hier sind die wichtigsten Änderungen, die vorgenommen werden müssen:

1. Tokenization und Input-Formate

Die Art und Weise, wie du die Eingabedaten für den Modellaufbau vorbereitest, kann verbessert werden, um sicherzustellen, dass die Daten korrekt verarbeitet werden.

Problem:

  • In deiner decode_sequence-Funktion wird der Tokenizer in einer Weise verwendet, die möglicherweise zu unerwartetem Verhalten führt, besonders bei der Vorbereitung von input_ids. Der Tokenizer erwartet Eingaben als Text und nicht als Token-IDs.

Lösung:

Verwende return_tensors="pt" für PyTorch, oder für TensorFlow return_tensors="np" für NumPy, und achte darauf, dass die input_ids korrekt verarbeitet werden.

2. Initialisierung des Modells und der Tokenizer

Es sieht so aus, als ob du die Eingabe- und Zielsequenzen aus dem T5Tokenizer verwendest, aber du musst sicherstellen, dass die Tokenizer sowohl für das Training als auch für die Inferenz richtig angewendet werden.

Lösung:

Beim Aufruf der decode_sequence-Funktion und der Verarbeitung der Eingabedaten musst du den Tokenizer konsistent verwenden, insbesondere für das padding und die max_length. Dies stellt sicher, dass die Eingabesequenzen korrekt in numerische Token umgewandelt werden, die das Modell verstehen kann.

3. Verwendung von <start> und <end> Tokens

Stelle sicher, dass du die speziellen Tokens für das Starten und Beenden der Sequenz korrekt im target_text anwendest.

Lösung:

Wenn du das Modell trainierst und beim Erstellen der Zieltexte, achte darauf, dass du explizite Tokens wie <start> und <end> hinzufügst, um das Ende und den Beginn der Sequenz zu kennzeichnen. In deiner decode_sequence-Methode solltest du auch auf das Ende der Sequenz achten und das passende Token verwenden.

Beispielanpassungen:

Hier ist eine angepasste Version des Codes mit den erwähnten Änderungen:

python
def decode_sequence(input_text):
    # Tokenisierung der Eingabe
    input_ids = tokenizer(input_text, return_tensors="np", padding=True, truncation=True, max_length=512)["input_ids"]
    
    # Encoder Vorhersage
    encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = encoder_model.predict(input_ids)
    states_value = [state_h, state_c]

    # Decoder Startsequenz initialisieren
    target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1))
    target_seq[0, 0] = tokenizer.convert_tokens_to_ids('<pad>')  # Padding Token als Startwert

    stop_condition = False
    decoded_sentence = ""

    # Decoder Schleife
    while not stop_condition:
        output_tokens, h, c = decoder_model.predict([target_seq, encoder_outputs] + states_value)
        
        # Das nächste Wort bestimmen
        sampled_token_index = np.argmax(output_tokens[0, -1, :])
        sampled_word = tokenizer.decode([sampled_token_index])

        decoded_sentence += " " + sampled_word

        # Bedingung für das Stoppen der Sequenz
        if sampled_word.strip() == "</s>" or len(decoded_sentence.split()) > 50:
            stop_condition = True

        # Target Sequence für den nächsten Schritt vorbereiten
        target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1))
        target_seq[0, 0] = sampled_token_index
        states_value = [h, c]

    return decoded_sentence.strip()

# Testen der Funktion
test_text = ["Angela Merkel became Chancellor in 2011 after winning the election"]
summary = decode_sequence(test_text[0])
print(summary)

4. Beachten der Zielsequenzen für das Training

Vergewissere dich, dass während des Trainings auch die Zielsequenzen (decoder_target_data) richtig vorbereitet sind. Du hast es im Code kommentiert, aber es ist wichtig, sicherzustellen, dass du den Decoder-Input korrekt weitergibst.

Zusammenfassung:

  • Verwende die korrekte padding- und max_length-Einstellung im Tokenizer.

  • Achte darauf, die speziellen Tokens (<start>, <end>, <pad>) korrekt zu verwenden.

  • Sorge dafür, dass die Sequenzen sowohl im Training als auch in der Inferenz richtig verarbeitet werden.

Versuche diese Anpassungen und überprüfe, ob das Modell korrekt funktioniert!

Du:
import keras import numpy as np from keras.preprocessing.text import Tokenizer from keras import Input, Model, layers from datasets import load_dataset import tensorflow as tf from keras_preprocessing.sequence import pad_sequences import pickle from transformers import T5Tokenizer from keras.layers import Attention, Concatenate dataset = load_dataset("abisee/cnn_dailymail", "3.0.0") # # input_text = [ # "Angela Merkel wurde 2011 Bundeskanzlerin, nachdem sie die Wahl gewonnen hatte", # "Bayer hat vorgestern am Abend 5:3 gegen Dortmund gewonnen, war super das Spiel", # "Die deutsche Wirtschaft wächst trotz der internationalen Unsicherheiten stetig weiter.", # "Tesla hat kürzlich sein neues Elektroauto-Modell vorgestellt, das eine Reichweite von über 600 Kilometern bietet." # ] # # target_text = [ # "Angela Merkel wurde 2011 Bundeskanzlerin", # "Bayern gewann 5:3 gegen Dortmund", # "Deutsche Wirtschaft wächst trotz Unsicherheiten", # "Tesla stellt neues Elektroauto vor" # ] input_text = dataset['train']['article'][:10000] # Artikel aus dem Datensatz target_text = dataset['train']['highlights'][:10000] # #Tokenizer preparation # input_tokenizer = Tokenizer() # input_tokenizer.fit_on_texts(input_text) # formats the text into numbers like this TextVectorization # input_sequences = input_tokenizer.texts_to_sequences(input_text) # # start_token = '<start>' # end_token = '<end>' # target_text_with_tokens = [start_token + " " + text + " " + end_token for text in target_text] # OWN TOKENIZER # # target_tokenizer = Tokenizer(filters='',num_words=20000) # target_tokenizer.fit_on_texts(target_text_with_tokens) # target_sequences = target_tokenizer.texts_to_sequences(target_text_with_tokens) tokenizer = T5Tokenizer.from_pretrained("t5-small") input_encodings = tokenizer(input_text, padding="longest", truncation=True, return_tensors="np") target_encodings = tokenizer(target_text, padding="longest", truncation=True, return_tensors="np") encoder_input_data = input_encodings["input_ids"] decoder_input_data = target_encodings["input_ids"] vocab_size = tokenizer.vocab_size def trainTextSummarizer(): # Data preparation # max_encoder_seq_length = max(len(seq) for seq in input_sequences) # declares the max len for input and target # max_decoder_seq_length = max(len(seq) for seq in target_sequences) # # encoder_input_data = pad_sequences(input_sequences, maxlen=max_encoder_seq_length, # padding="post") # secures that all sequences have the same length if # # they are too short, # # padding is comming # decoder_input_data = pad_sequences(target_sequences, maxlen=max_decoder_seq_length, # padding="post") # parameter # num_encoder_tokens = len(input_tokenizer.word_index) + 1 # number of unique words plus 1 for the padding # num_decoder_tokens = len(target_tokenizer.word_index) + 1 # same here latent_dim = 128 # neuron count # encoder # encoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,)) # Input layer for the encoder with no declared shape # enc_emb = layers.Embedding(num_encoder_tokens, latent_dim)( # encoder_inputs) # changes every word from input to a vector with strict dimension the latent dimension (neurons) # # encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_state=True)(enc_emb) # encoder_states = [state_h, state_c] # brain status is returned, the most important features of the text # # # decoder # decoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,)) # Input layer for the decoder # dec_emb = layers.Embedding(num_decoder_tokens, latent_dim)( # decoder_inputs) # changes every word from input to a vector with strict dimension the latent dimension (neurons) # # decoder_outputs, _, _ =layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_sequences=True, return_state=True)(dec_emb, # initial_state=encoder_states) # brain status is returned (Not real) # decoder_outputs =layers.Dense(num_decoder_tokens, activation="softmax")(decoder_outputs) # # calculates the probability for each word in the target vocab from the output of the LSTM layer (softmax == all probability together equals 1 ) encoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,), name="encoder_inputs") enc_emb = layers.Embedding(input_dim=vocab_size, output_dim=latent_dim, name="encoder_embedding")( encoder_inputs) encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_sequences=True, return_state=True, name="encoder_lstm")(enc_emb) encoder_states = [state_h, state_c] decoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,), name="decoder_inputs") dec_emb = layers.Embedding(input_dim=vocab_size, output_dim=latent_dim, name="decoder_embedding")( decoder_inputs) decoder_lstm_outputs, _, _ = layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_sequences=True, return_state=True, name="decoder_lstm")(dec_emb, initial_state=encoder_states) # Attention Layer attention = layers.Attention(name="attention_layer")([decoder_lstm_outputs, encoder_outputs]) decoder_combined_context = layers.Concatenate(axis=-1)([decoder_lstm_outputs, attention]) # Output decoder_outputs = layers.Dense(vocab_size, activation="softmax", name="output_dense")(decoder_combined_context) model = Model([encoder_inputs, decoder_inputs], decoder_outputs) loss_fn = tf.keras.losses.SparseCategoricalCrossentropy(from_logits=False, reduction='none') def masked_loss(y_true, y_pred): loss = loss_fn(y_true, y_pred) mask = tf.cast(tf.not_equal(y_true, 0), dtype=loss.dtype) # 0 = <pad> return tf.reduce_mean(loss * mask) model.compile(optimizer='adam', loss=masked_loss, metrics=['accuracy']) model.summary() decoder_target_data = np.zeros_like(decoder_input_data) decoder_target_data[:, :-1] = decoder_input_data[:, 1:] model.fit([encoder_input_data, decoder_input_data], np.expand_dims(decoder_target_data, -1), batch_size=32, epochs=15) model.save("SummarizerModel.keras") # with open("input_tokenizer.pkl", "wb") as f: # pickle.dump(input_tokenizer, f) # with open("target_tokenizer.pkl", "wb") as f: # pickle.dump(target_tokenizer, f) # encoder takes the most important information out of the input text, the decoder gets this text and try's to build a new text concluding the important information # and all this is happening because the tokenizer makes the input to numbers and then via embedding vectors are generated in the encoder which are representing the state of the "brain" and # the decoder takes this and trys formating a new text # Vectors are essential because tokenizer don't learn with semantic but embeddings do, for words with same semantic they receive same vectors e.g. [0.3, 0,31] word 1 [0.32, 0.34] word 2 # each word is a vector as long as the latent dimension that why it's used in the embeddings with tf.device('/GPU:0'): # /GPU:0 ist der Index für die erste GPU trainTextSummarizer() model = keras.models.load_model("SummarizerModel.keras") encoder_inputs = model.input[0] encoder_embedding = model.get_layer("encoder_embedding")(encoder_inputs) encoder_outputs, state_h_enc, state_c_enc = model.get_layer("encoder_lstm")(encoder_embedding) # LSTM Layers encoder_states = [state_h_enc, state_c_enc] encoder_model = keras.Model(encoder_inputs, [encoder_outputs, state_h_enc, state_c_enc]) # Decoder Model decoder_inputs = model.input[1] decoder_state_input_h = keras.Input(shape=(128,), name="decoder_state_input_h") decoder_state_input_c = keras.Input(shape=(128,), name="decoder_state_input_c") decoder_states_inputs = [decoder_state_input_h, decoder_state_input_c] decoder_hidden_state_input = Input(shape=(None, 128), name="decoder_hidden_input") dec_emb_layer = model.get_layer("decoder_embedding") dec_emb = dec_emb_layer(decoder_inputs) decoder_lstm = model.get_layer("decoder_lstm") decoder_lstm_outputs, state_h, state_c = decoder_lstm( dec_emb, initial_state=decoder_states_inputs ) attention_layer = model.get_layer("attention_layer") attention_output = attention_layer([decoder_lstm_outputs, decoder_hidden_state_input]) decoder_combined_context = Concatenate(axis=-1)([decoder_lstm_outputs, attention_output]) decoder_states = [state_h, state_c] decoder_dense = model.get_layer("output_dense") decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_combined_context) decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_outputs) decoder_model = keras.Model( [decoder_inputs,decoder_hidden_state_input] + decoder_states_inputs, [decoder_outputs] + decoder_states, name="decoder_model" ) # grabs from the pretrained model, the layers and build two new separate models # during inference they need to separately def decode_sequence(input_text): # Tokenisierung der Eingabe input_ids = tokenizer(input_text, return_tensors="np", padding=True, truncation=True, max_length=512)["input_ids"] # Encoder Vorhersage encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = encoder_model.predict(input_ids) states_value = [state_h, state_c] # Decoder Startsequenz initialisieren target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1)) target_seq[0, 0] = tokenizer.convert_tokens_to_ids('<pad>') # Padding Token als Startwert stop_condition = False decoded_sentence = "" # Decoder Schleife while not stop_condition: output_tokens, h, c = decoder_model.predict([target_seq, encoder_outputs] + states_value) # Das nächste Wort bestimmen sampled_token_index = np.argmax(output_tokens[0, -1, :]) sampled_word = tokenizer.decode([sampled_token_index]) decoded_sentence += " " + sampled_word # Bedingung für das Stoppen der Sequenz if sampled_word.strip() == "</s>" or len(decoded_sentence.split()) > 50: stop_condition = True # Target Sequence für den nächsten Schritt vorbereiten target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1)) target_seq[0, 0] = sampled_token_index states_value = [h, c] return decoded_sentence.strip() test_text = ["Angela Merkel became Chancellor in 2011 after winning the election, just with 50% which is really crazy and cool"] summary = decode_sequence(test_text[0]) print(summary) also passt der Code jetzt ja oder nein
ChatGPT:

Der Code sieht jetzt viel vollständiger aus, aber es gibt noch ein paar Dinge, die verbessert werden könnten oder die möglicherweise Fehler verursachen könnten. Hier sind einige Punkte, die beachtet werden sollten:

1. Tokenizer und Modell-Kompatibilität:

  • Du verwendest den T5Tokenizer, aber es wird nicht immer klar, wie der Tokenizer für die Eingabe und die Ausgabe des Modells genau angepasst wird. Stelle sicher, dass das Modell und der Tokenizer korrekt miteinander kompatibel sind, besonders wenn du die Vorhersagen in einer speziellen Weise decodierst.

  • Der decode_sequence-Prozess scheint auf den T5-Tokenisierer abgestimmt zu sein, aber es wäre besser, die Start- und End-Tokens (<pad>, <start>, <end>) explizit zu behandeln, je nachdem, wie der T5-Tokenizer die Token verarbeitet.

2. Maximale Eingabelänge:

  • In decode_sequence verwendest du max_length=512, was für die meisten Modelle eine gute Wahl ist. Beachte jedoch, dass das Modell bei längeren Texten diese möglicherweise abschnitten muss.

3. Fehlerbehebung in der decode_sequence-Methode:

  • Wenn der Text das Ende erreicht, könnte der Vergleich sampled_word.strip() == "</s>" fehlschlagen, da T5 in der Regel das End-Token als </s> hat, aber du solltest sicherstellen, dass du auch den richtigen Token verwendest, der zum Modell passt (denn "<s>" oder "<pad>" könnten auch Optionen sein).

4. Aufruf von decoder_model.predict:

  • In der decode_sequence-Methode rufst du decoder_model.predict([target_seq, encoder_outputs] + states_value). Da du das Ergebnis von encoder_model.predict in encoder_outputs speicherst, ist es wichtig, sicherzustellen, dass die Dimensionen übereinstimmen, insbesondere, da du decoder_hidden_state_input verwendest, das eventuell nicht richtig behandelt wird.

Verbesserungsvorschläge:

  • Teste den Code zunächst auf kleineren Eingaben und validiere, dass das Modell die Textzusammenfassungen tatsächlich generiert.

  • Teste auch, ob der Aufruf von model.predict die erwarteten Vorhersagen liefert und dass das End-Token korrekt erkannt wird.

Abgesehen davon sollte der Code im Wesentlichen funktionieren, vorausgesetzt, das Modell wurde richtig trainiert.

"C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\losses.py", line 152, in __call__ losses = call_fn(y_true, y_pred) File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\losses.py", line 272, in call return ag_fn(y_true, y_pred, **self._fn_kwargs) File "C:\Users\Henri\Videos\ImageClassifier\TextSummarizer.py", line 112, in masked_loss return tf.reduce_mean(loss * mask) Node: 'masked_loss/mul' required broadcastable shapes [[{{node masked_loss/mul}}]] [Op:__inference_train_function_5876] Process finished with exit code 1 something wrong witht the def masked_loss(y_true, y_pred): loss = loss_fn(y_true, y_pred) mask = tf.cast(tf.not_equal(y_true, 0), dtype=loss.dtype) # 0 = <pad> return tf.reduce_mean(loss * mask)funktion
ChatGPT:

The error you're encountering suggests that there is a shape mismatch between the loss and the mask tensors when you try to perform the element-wise multiplication in the masked_loss function.

In the line:

python
return tf.reduce_mean(loss * mask)

The operation loss * mask requires that both loss and mask have the same shape, but in your case, they don't. To fix this, you should make sure that both tensors (loss and mask) have compatible shapes before performing the multiplication.

Here’s how you can modify the masked_loss function to avoid the error:

  1. Ensure that both y_true and y_pred have the same shape.

  2. Check the shape of the mask to ensure it's broadcastable to match the shape of the loss.

Try the following modification:

python
def masked_loss(y_true, y_pred):
    loss = loss_fn(y_true, y_pred)
    
    # Create mask where values of y_true are not equal to zero (padding tokens)
    mask = tf.cast(tf.not_equal(y_true, 0), dtype=loss.dtype)  # 0 = <pad>
    
    # Ensure mask is the same shape as the loss
    mask = tf.broadcast_to(mask, loss.shape)
    
    return tf.reduce_mean(loss * mask)

In this modification, tf.broadcast_to(mask, loss.shape) ensures that the mask has the same shape as the loss tensor, allowing the element-wise multiplication to work correctly.

Let me know if this resolves the issue or if you need further assistance!

Du:
Epoch 1/15 Traceback (most recent call last): File "C:\Users\Henri\Videos\ImageClassifier\TextSummarizer.py", line 143, in <module> trainTextSummarizer() File "C:\Users\Henri\Videos\ImageClassifier\TextSummarizer.py", line 125, in trainTextSummarizer model.fit([encoder_input_data, decoder_input_data], File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\utils\traceback_utils.py", line 70, in error_handler raise e.with_traceback(filtered_tb) from None File "C:\Users\Henri\AppData\Local\Temp\__autograph_generated_fileibrqx2e0.py", line 15, in tf__train_function retval_ = ag__.converted_call(ag__.ld(step_function), (ag__.ld(self), ag__.ld(iterator)), None, fscope) File "C:\Users\Henri\AppData\Local\Temp\__autograph_generated_file7etpwz_4.py", line 13, in tf__masked_loss mask = ag__.converted_call(ag__.ld(tf).broadcast_to, (ag__.ld(mask), ag__.ld(loss).shape), None, fscope) ValueError: in user code: File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\engine\training.py", line 1160, in train_function * return step_function(self, iterator) File "C:\Users\Henri\Videos\ImageClassifier\TextSummarizer.py", line 115, in masked_loss * mask = tf.broadcast_to(mask, loss.shape) ValueError: Tried to convert 'shape' to a tensor and failed. Error: Cannot convert a partially known TensorShape (None, 122) to a Tensor. Process finished with exit code 1
ChatGPT:

The error you're encountering is related to TensorFlow's inability to handle the loss.shape as it is a dynamically determined shape (None for batch size). This is common when working with tensors that have unknown batch dimensions (i.e., the batch size is not fixed and is represented as None in the shape).

To address this issue, you should try to explicitly set the shape of the mask without relying on loss.shape. Instead, you can use the shape of y_true to broadcast the mask, assuming that y_true and y_pred share the same shape.

Here’s how you can modify the masked_loss function to fix this:

python
def masked_loss(y_true, y_pred):
    loss = loss_fn(y_true, y_pred)
    
    # Create mask where values of y_true are not equal to zero (padding tokens)
    mask = tf.cast(tf.not_equal(y_true, 0), dtype=loss.dtype)  # 0 = <pad>
    
    # Broadcast the mask to match the shape of loss
    mask = tf.broadcast_to(mask, tf.shape(loss))
    
    return tf.reduce_mean(loss * mask)

Explanation:

  • tf.shape(loss) returns the fully known shape of the loss tensor, which should resolve the issue with broadcasting.

  • mask will now be broadcasted to the shape of the loss tensor without relying on loss.shape.

This should fix the error you're seeing. Try it and let me know if it works!

Du:
ValueError: Shape must be at most rank 2 but is rank 3 for '{{node masked_loss/BroadcastTo}} = BroadcastTo[T=DT_FLOAT, Tidx=DT_INT32](masked_loss/Cast, masked_loss/Shape)' with input shapes: [?,122,1], [2].
ChatGPT:

The issue you're seeing occurs because you're trying to broadcast a 3-dimensional tensor ([?, 122, 1]) to a shape that has only 2 dimensions ([2]). This indicates that loss has an extra dimension (likely the time or sequence length), which mask is not compatible with unless you handle the extra dimension properly.

You can fix this by adjusting the mask to match the shape of loss correctly by ensuring it works across the sequence length dimension.

Here’s an adjusted version of your masked_loss function:

python
def masked_loss(y_true, y_pred):
    loss = loss_fn(y_true, y_pred)
    
    # Create mask where values of y_true are not equal to zero (padding tokens)
    mask = tf.cast(tf.not_equal(y_true, 0), dtype=loss.dtype)  # 0 = <pad>
    
    # Expand mask dimensions if needed to match the rank of loss (3D in this case)
    if len(mask.shape) < len(loss.shape):
        mask = tf.expand_dims(mask, axis=-1)  # Add a dimension to match 3D if necessary
    
    # Now, mask should have the same shape as loss, and broadcasting should work
    mask = tf.broadcast_to(mask, tf.shape(loss))  # Broadcast to match loss shape
    
    return tf.reduce_mean(loss * mask)

Key Changes:

  1. tf.expand_dims(mask, axis=-1): This ensures that the mask has an extra dimension (for the third axis) if needed, to match the rank of the loss tensor (which seems to be 3-dimensional).

  2. Broadcasting: The mask is broadcasted to the shape of the loss tensor (tf.shape(loss)).

Explanation:

  • y_true likely has the shape [batch_size, sequence_length], and loss probably has the shape [batch_size, sequence_length, 1] (i.e., each token has a loss value).

  • By expanding the mask along the last axis (if necessary) and broadcasting it to the loss tensor's shape, the element-wise multiplication (loss * mask) will work as expected.

Give this a try and let me know if it resolves the issue!

Du:
C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\python.exe C:\Users\Henri\Videos\ImageClassifier\TextSummarizer.py You are using the default legacy behaviour of the <class 'transformers.models.t5.tokenization_t5.T5Tokenizer'>. This is expected, and simply means that the legacy (previous) behavior will be used so nothing changes for you. If you want to use the new behaviour, set legacy=False. params: 16,679,168 Trainable params: 16,679,168 Non-trainable params: 0 __________________________________________________________________________________________________ Epoch 1/15 Traceback (most recent call last): File "C:\Users\Henri\Videos\ImageClassifier\TextSummarizer.py", line 144, in <module> trainTextSummarizer() File "C:\Users\Henri\Videos\ImageClassifier\TextSummarizer.py", line 126, in trainTextSummarizer model.fit([encoder_input_data, decoder_input_data], File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\utils\traceback_utils.py", line 70, in error_handler raise e.with_traceback(filtered_tb) from None File "C:\Users\Henri\AppData\Local\Temp\__autograph_generated_filew1ak2bg5.py", line 15, in tf__train_function retval_ = ag__.converted_call(ag__.ld(step_function), (ag__.ld(self), ag__.ld(iterator)), None, fscope) File "C:\Users\Henri\AppData\Local\Temp\__autograph_generated_file6cyeswtn.py", line 29, in tf__masked_loss mask = ag__.converted_call(ag__.ld(tf).broadcast_to, (ag__.ld(mask), ag__.converted_call(ag__.ld(tf).shape, (ag__.ld(loss),), None, fscope)), None, fscope) ValueError: in user code: File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\engine\training.py", line 1160, in train_function * return step_function(self, iterator) File "C:\Users\Henri\Videos\ImageClassifier\TextSummarizer.py", line 116, in masked_loss * mask = tf.broadcast_to(mask, tf.shape(loss)) ValueError: Shape must be at most rank 2 but is rank 3 for '{{node masked_loss/BroadcastTo}} = BroadcastTo[T=DT_FLOAT, Tidx=DT_INT32](masked_loss/Cast, masked_loss/Shape)' with input shapes: [?,122,1], [2]. Process finished with exit code 1 kriege immer noch den Error und ist es überhaupt wichtig masked loss zu nutzen
ChatGPT:

Danke für die genauere Fehlermeldung. Der Fehler bleibt bestehen, weil die mask- und loss-Tensors unterschiedliche Ranks haben, konkret:

  • loss.shape ist 3-dimensional, z. B. [batch_size, sequence_length, 1]

  • mask.shape ist nur 2-dimensional, z. B. [batch_size, sequence_length]

🔧 Lösung: Korrektes Broadcast-fähiges mask erzeugen

Du musst mask so anpassen, dass es die gleiche Dimension wie loss hat, also auch 3D ist:

python
def masked_loss(y_true, y_pred):
    loss = loss_fn(y_true, y_pred)  # loss shape: (batch_size, sequence_len, 1)

    # Maske: gleiche Form wie y_true (batch_size, sequence_len)
    mask = tf.cast(tf.not_equal(y_true, 0), dtype=loss.dtype)

    # mask -> (batch_size, sequence_len, 1) für korrekte Multiplikation
    mask = tf.expand_dims(mask, axis=-1)

    # Nun mask hat gleiche Rank wie loss => kein Broadcast Error
    loss *= mask

    return tf.reduce_sum(loss) / tf.reduce_sum(mask)

✅ Damit vermeidest du den Broadcast-Fehler vollständig.

❓Ist masked_loss überhaupt notwendig?

Kurz gesagt: Ja, wenn du mit Padding arbeitest.

Wenn dein Decoder-Eingabesequenzen Padding-Tokens (0) enthalten, und du den Loss nicht maskierst, dann:

  • Lernst du auf „nutzlosen“ Tokens (Padding).

  • Das Modell wird ineffizient und ungenau (übermäßiger Fokus auf Nullen).

Wenn du komplett ohne Padding arbeitest (sehr unüblich in NLP), brauchst du keine Maskierung.

🧠 Alternativen

Falls du loss_fn z. B. SparseCategoricalCrossentropy nutzt, kannst du direkt sagen:

python
loss_fn = tf.keras.losses.SparseCategoricalCrossentropy(from_logits=False, reduction='none')

Dann gibt loss_fn den Loss pro Token zurück, und du kannst selber maskieren wie oben.

✅ Fazit

Du bekommst den Fehler, weil mask 2D und loss 3D ist. Mit tf.expand_dims(mask, -1) passt du das korrekt an.

Möchtest du, dass ich dir den vollständigen Loss-Block (inkl. loss_fn) für deinen Fall gebe?

Du:
313/313 [==============================] - 44s 140ms/step - loss: 8352.2607 - accuracy: 0.6468 Traceback (most recent call last): File "C:\Users\Henri\Videos\ImageClassifier\TextSummarizer.py", line 146, in <module> model = keras.models.load_model("SummarizerModel.keras") File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\utils\traceback_utils.py", line 70, in error_handler raise e.with_traceback(filtered_tb) from None File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\utils\generic_utils.py", line 769, in deserialize_keras_object raise ValueError( ValueError: Unknown loss function: masked_loss. Please ensure this object is passed to the custom_objects argument. See https://www.tensorflow.org/guide/keras/save_and_serialize#registering_the_custom_object for details. Process finished with exit code 1 wie macht man das muss ich beim loaden dann sagern custom objects
ChatGPT:

Ja, genau! Wenn du ein Modell mit einer benutzerdefinierten Funktion wie masked_loss speicherst und später wieder laden willst, musst du beim Laden diese Funktion explizit angeben über das Argument custom_objects.

✅ So funktioniert’s:

Wenn du dein Modell mit einer eigenen Loss-Funktion wie masked_loss geladen hast, verwende:

python
from TextSummarizer import masked_loss  # oder direkt aus dem Code, wo du masked_loss definiert hast

model = keras.models.load_model("SummarizerModel.keras", custom_objects={"masked_loss": masked_loss})

💡 Alternative mit @keras.utils.register_keras_serializable

Wenn du masked_loss öfter speicherst/lädst, kannst du es serialisierbar machen:

python
from tensorflow.keras.utils import register_keras_serializable

@register_keras_serializable()
def masked_loss(y_true, y_pred):
    ...

Dann merkt sich Keras diese Funktion beim Speichern – kein custom_objects mehr nötig beim Laden!

🔁 Zusammenfassung

SituationLösung
Du hast masked_loss im Modell verwendetload_model(..., custom_objects={"masked_loss": masked_loss})
Du willst es saubererNutze @register_keras_serializable

Möchtest du auch, dass ich dir zeige, wie man masked_loss + Modell richtig speichert und lädt inkl. Beispiel?

Du:
Das Vokabulr also die Fähigkeit zu generealisieren hängt vom Tokenizer ab oder ? also wenn der Gut ist, kann man bessere generalisieren
ChatGPT:

Ja, absolut richtig – die Fähigkeit deines Modells zu generalisieren hängt maßgeblich vom Tokenizer ab. Hier ist, warum:

🔑 Warum der Tokenizer entscheidend für die Generalisierung ist:

  1. Vokabulargrenze & OOV (Out-Of-Vocabulary):
    Ein guter Tokenizer (z. B. mit Subword-Tokenisierung wie bei SentencePiece oder Byte-Pair Encoding) kann auch unbekannte Wörter sinnvoll zerlegen.
    ➤ So kann das Modell neue Wörter verstehen, die es nie gesehen hat.

  2. Token-Länge vs. Kontext:
    Schlechte Tokenizer zerschneiden zu aggressiv oder zu grob – das führt zu schlechteren Kontextrepräsentationen.
    ➤ Ein guter Tokenizer balanciert zwischen Granularität (z. B. Wortstämme) und Effizienz.

  3. Semantische Nähe durch Tokens:
    Tokenizer, die ähnliche Wörter auch ähnlich tokenisieren, helfen dem Modell, semantische Ähnlichkeit zu erkennen.

🔄 Beispiel:

WortBPE Tokenizer (gut)Word-level Tokenizer (schwach)
"unhappiness"["un", "happiness"]["unhappiness"]
"happier"["happi", "er"]["happier"]

Der erste Tokenizer erkennt die gemeinsamen Morpheme → bessere Generalisierung.

✅ Fazit:

Ein leistungsfähiger Tokenizer erweitert das effektive Vokabular des Modells, erhöht die Robustheit gegenüber neuen Begriffen und fördert Generalisierung deutlich.

Welchen Tokenizer verwendest du aktuell – z. B. T5Tokenizer, BERTTokenizer, oder etwas Eigenes?

Du:
Traceback (most recent call last): File "C:\Users\Henri\Videos\ImageClassifier\TextSummarizer.py", line 219, in <module> summary = decode_sequence(test_text[0]) File "C:\Users\Henri\Videos\ImageClassifier\TextSummarizer.py", line 199, in decode_sequence output_tokens, h, c = decoder_model.predict([target_seq, encoder_outputs] + states_value) File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\utils\traceback_utils.py", line 70, in error_handler raise e.with_traceback(filtered_tb) from None File "C:\Users\Henri\AppData\Local\Temp\__autograph_generated_filejsqyvyji.py", line 15, in tf__predict_function retval_ = ag__.converted_call(ag__.ld(step_function), (ag__.ld(self), ag__.ld(iterator)), None, fscope) ValueError: in user code: File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\engine\training.py", line 2041, in predict_function * return step_function(self, iterator) File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\engine\training.py", line 2027, in step_function ** outputs = model.distribute_strategy.run(run_step, args=(data,)) File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\engine\training.py", line 2015, in run_step ** outputs = model.predict_step(data) File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\engine\training.py", line 1983, in predict_step return self(x, training=False) File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\utils\traceback_utils.py", line 70, in error_handler raise e.with_traceback(filtered_tb) from None File "C:\Users\Henri\miniconda3\envs\tf-gpu\lib\site-packages\keras\engine\input_spec.py", line 277, in assert_input_compatibility raise ValueError( ValueError: Exception encountered when calling layer "decoder_model" " f"(type Functional). Input 0 of layer "output_dense" is incompatible with the layer: expected axis -1 of input shape to have value 256, but received input with shape (None, 1, 32000) Call arguments received by layer "decoder_model" " f"(type Functional): • inputs=('tf.Tensor(shape=(None, 1), dtype=float32)', 'tf.Tensor(shape=(None, 23, 128), dtype=float32)', 'tf.Tensor(shape=(None, 128), dtype=float32)', 'tf.Tensor(shape=(None, 128), dtype=float32)') • training=False • mask=None hier sagt er läuft nicht while not stop_condition: output_tokens, h, c = decoder_model.predict([target_seq, encoder_outputs] + states_value) # Das nächste Wort bestimmen sampled_token_index = np.argmax(output_tokens[0, -1, :]) sampled_word = tokenizer.decode([sampled_token_index]) decoded_sentence += " " + sampled_word # Bedingung für das Stoppen der Sequenz if sampled_word.strip() == "</s>" or len(decoded_sentence.split()) > 50: stop_condition = True # Target Sequence für den nächsten Schritt vorbereiten target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1)) target_seq[0, 0] = sampled_token_index states_value = [h, c] return decoded_sentence.strip()
ChatGPT:

Der Fehler zeigt deutlich:

"expected axis -1 of input shape to have value 256, but received input with shape (None, 1, 32000)"

Das bedeutet: Die Dense-Schicht am Ende deines Decoders erwartet eine Eingabe mit 256 Features, bekommt aber ein One-Hot-Encoding mit 32.000 Features (vermutlich dein Vokabular).

🔍 Ursache:

Du gibst target_seq vermutlich als One-Hot-Encoding oder als Token-ID rein, aber nicht so, wie es dein Decoder erwartet. Der Decoder erwartet wahrscheinlich embedded Vektoren mit Dimension 256, nicht rohe Token-IDs oder One-Hot.

✅ Lösung:

Lösung 1: Embedding-Layer vor dem Decoder-Ausgang nutzen

Wenn dein decoder_model den Token-ID-Input (target_seq) direkt bekommt, musst du:

  • Entweder eine passende Embedding-Schicht auch im decoder_model wieder einbauen,

  • oder das Eingabetoken vorher durch denselben Embedding-Prozess schicken, den du im Training genutzt hast.

Beispiel:

python
# Statt:
target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1))
target_seq[0, 0] = sampled_token_index

# Nutze den Embedding-Vektor des Tokens (z. B. mit keras embedding-Schicht oder vorher erstelltem Layer)
embedded_target_seq = decoder_embedding_layer(target_seq)
output_tokens, h, c = decoder_model.predict([embedded_target_seq, encoder_outputs] + states_value)

Lösung 2: Überprüfe, wie dein decoder_model definiert wurde

Wenn du dein decoder_model manuell definiert hast, muss er genau die gleichen Schichten (z. B. Embedding-Schicht) enthalten wie das Training. Wenn die Embedding-Schicht fehlt oder nicht übernommen wurde, kommt es zu diesem Fehler.

🛠 Nächster Schritt:

  • Schau dir an, wie dein ursprüngliches Modell im Training definiert war.

  • Stelle sicher, dass dein decoder_model beim inference decoding (also bei decode_sequence) den gleichen Aufbau hat, besonders:

    • Die Eingabe (target_seq) wird durch Embedding geschickt, bevor sie in die LSTM geht.

    • Die Dense-Schicht erwartet (batch_size, timesteps, 256), nicht (batch_size, timesteps, vocab_size) als Eingabe.

Wenn du magst, zeig mir bitte den Aufbau deines decoder_model, dann sage ich dir genau, was du anpassen musst.

Du:
# Decoder Model decoder_inputs = model.input[1] decoder_state_input_h = keras.Input(shape=(128,), name="decoder_state_input_h") decoder_state_input_c = keras.Input(shape=(128,), name="decoder_state_input_c") decoder_states_inputs = [decoder_state_input_h, decoder_state_input_c] decoder_hidden_state_input = Input(shape=(None, 128), name="decoder_hidden_input") dec_emb_layer = model.get_layer("decoder_embedding") dec_emb = dec_emb_layer(decoder_inputs) decoder_lstm = model.get_layer("decoder_lstm") decoder_lstm_outputs, state_h, state_c = decoder_lstm( dec_emb, initial_state=decoder_states_inputs ) attention_layer = model.get_layer("attention_layer") attention_output = attention_layer([decoder_lstm_outputs, decoder_hidden_state_input]) decoder_combined_context = Concatenate(axis=-1)([decoder_lstm_outputs, attention_output]) decoder_states = [state_h, state_c] decoder_dense = model.get_layer("output_dense") decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_combined_context) decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_outputs) decoder_model = keras.Model( [decoder_inputs,decoder_hidden_state_input] + decoder_states_inputs, [decoder_outputs] + decoder_states, name="decoder_model" ) # grabs from the pretrained model, the layers and build two new separate models # during inference they need to separately def decode_sequence(input_text): # Tokenisierung der Eingabe input_ids = tokenizer(input_text, return_tensors="np", padding=True, truncation=True, max_length=512)["input_ids"] # Encoder Vorhersage encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = encoder_model.predict(input_ids) states_value = [state_h, state_c] # Decoder Startsequenz initialisieren target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1)) target_seq[0, 0] = tokenizer.convert_tokens_to_ids('<pad>') # Padding Token als Startwert stop_condition = False decoded_sentence = "" # Decoder Schleife while not stop_condition: output_tokens, h, c = decoder_model.predict([target_seq, encoder_outputs] + states_value) # Das nächste Wort bestimmen sampled_token_index = np.argmax(output_tokens[0, -1, :]) sampled_word = tokenizer.decode([sampled_token_index])
ChatGPT:

Danke für deinen Code. Der Hauptfehler ist hier:

target_seq wird als Token-ID (integer) übergeben – aber deine decoder_model erwartet embedded Input-Vektoren, also die Ausgabe der Embedding-Schicht.

Allerdings verwendest du:

python
dec_emb_layer = model.get_layer("decoder_embedding")
dec_emb = dec_emb_layer(decoder_inputs)

Das bedeutet: Im decoder_model steckt die Embedding-Schicht schon drin, also solltest du target_seq als Token-ID übergeben – aber decoder_inputs in decoder_model muss dann auch wirklich target_seq sein.

🛠 ABER hier ist das Problem:

Du verwendest beim Inferenz-Call:

python
output_tokens, h, c = decoder_model.predict([target_seq, encoder_outputs] + states_value)

Aber dein decoder_model erwartet als erstes Input:

python
[decoder_inputs, decoder_hidden_state_input] + decoder_states_inputs

  • decoder_inputs → das ist target_seq (richtig)

  • decoder_hidden_state_input → das ist encoder_outputs (richtig)

  • decoder_states_inputs → das sind [state_h, state_c] (richtig)

Soweit korrekt, aber:

Der Fehler sagt:

pgsql
Input 0 of layer "output_dense" is incompatible with the layer: expected axis -1 of input shape to have value 256, but received input with shape (None, 1, 32000)

Das passiert nicht im Embedding, sondern weil du decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_outputs) doppelt aufrufst:

python
decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_combined_context)
decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_outputs)  # <-- HIER ist der Fehler!

✅ Lösung:

Entferne die zweite Zeile, du hast decoder_dense bereits einmal aufgerufen:

python
# FALSCH (du rufst decoder_dense 2x auf)
decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_combined_context)
decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_outputs)

# RICHTIG:
decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_combined_context)

📌 Fazit:

  • decoder_dense() wird doppelt aufgerufen → falsche Dimensionen entstehen → daher der Fehler.

  • Du übergibst target_seq korrekt als Token-ID, da deine decoder_model die decoder_embedding-Schicht enthält.

  • Deine Schleife decode_sequence() ist sonst korrekt aufgebaut.

Willst du auch den kompletten Decoder-Aufbau nochmal überprüft oder den gesamten Vorwärtsdurchlauf testen?

Du:
also passt der Code: import keras import numpy as np from keras.preprocessing.text import Tokenizer from keras import Input, Model, layers from datasets import load_dataset import tensorflow as tf from keras_preprocessing.sequence import pad_sequences import pickle from transformers import T5Tokenizer from keras.layers import Attention, Concatenate dataset = load_dataset("abisee/cnn_dailymail", "3.0.0") # # input_text = [ # "Angela Merkel wurde 2011 Bundeskanzlerin, nachdem sie die Wahl gewonnen hatte", # "Bayer hat vorgestern am Abend 5:3 gegen Dortmund gewonnen, war super das Spiel", # "Die deutsche Wirtschaft wächst trotz der internationalen Unsicherheiten stetig weiter.", # "Tesla hat kürzlich sein neues Elektroauto-Modell vorgestellt, das eine Reichweite von über 600 Kilometern bietet." # ] # # target_text = [ # "Angela Merkel wurde 2011 Bundeskanzlerin", # "Bayern gewann 5:3 gegen Dortmund", # "Deutsche Wirtschaft wächst trotz Unsicherheiten", # "Tesla stellt neues Elektroauto vor" # ] input_text = dataset['train']['article'][:10000] # Artikel aus dem Datensatz target_text = dataset['train']['highlights'][:10000] # #Tokenizer preparation # input_tokenizer = Tokenizer() # input_tokenizer.fit_on_texts(input_text) # formats the text into numbers like this TextVectorization # input_sequences = input_tokenizer.texts_to_sequences(input_text) # # start_token = '<start>' # end_token = '<end>' # target_text_with_tokens = [start_token + " " + text + " " + end_token for text in target_text] # OWN TOKENIZER # # target_tokenizer = Tokenizer(filters='',num_words=20000) # target_tokenizer.fit_on_texts(target_text_with_tokens) # target_sequences = target_tokenizer.texts_to_sequences(target_text_with_tokens) tokenizer = T5Tokenizer.from_pretrained("t5-small") input_encodings = tokenizer(input_text, padding="longest", truncation=True, return_tensors="np") target_encodings = tokenizer(target_text, padding="longest", truncation=True, return_tensors="np") encoder_input_data = input_encodings["input_ids"] decoder_input_data = target_encodings["input_ids"] vocab_size = tokenizer.vocab_size loss_fn = tf.keras.losses.SparseCategoricalCrossentropy(from_logits=False, reduction='none') def masked_loss(y_true, y_pred): loss = loss_fn(y_true, y_pred) mask = tf.cast(tf.not_equal(y_true, 0), dtype=loss.dtype) mask = tf.expand_dims(mask, axis=-1) loss *= mask return tf.reduce_sum(loss) / tf.reduce_sum(mask) def trainTextSummarizer(): # Data preparation # max_encoder_seq_length = max(len(seq) for seq in input_sequences) # declares the max len for input and target # max_decoder_seq_length = max(len(seq) for seq in target_sequences) # # encoder_input_data = pad_sequences(input_sequences, maxlen=max_encoder_seq_length, # padding="post") # secures that all sequences have the same length if # # they are too short, # # padding is comming # decoder_input_data = pad_sequences(target_sequences, maxlen=max_decoder_seq_length, # padding="post") # parameter # num_encoder_tokens = len(input_tokenizer.word_index) + 1 # number of unique words plus 1 for the padding # num_decoder_tokens = len(target_tokenizer.word_index) + 1 # same here latent_dim = 128 # neuron count # encoder # encoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,)) # Input layer for the encoder with no declared shape # enc_emb = layers.Embedding(num_encoder_tokens, latent_dim)( # encoder_inputs) # changes every word from input to a vector with strict dimension the latent dimension (neurons) # # encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_state=True)(enc_emb) # encoder_states = [state_h, state_c] # brain status is returned, the most important features of the text # # # decoder # decoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,)) # Input layer for the decoder # dec_emb = layers.Embedding(num_decoder_tokens, latent_dim)( # decoder_inputs) # changes every word from input to a vector with strict dimension the latent dimension (neurons) # # decoder_outputs, _, _ =layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_sequences=True, return_state=True)(dec_emb, # initial_state=encoder_states) # brain status is returned (Not real) # decoder_outputs =layers.Dense(num_decoder_tokens, activation="softmax")(decoder_outputs) # # calculates the probability for each word in the target vocab from the output of the LSTM layer (softmax == all probability together equals 1 ) encoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,), name="encoder_inputs") enc_emb = layers.Embedding(input_dim=vocab_size, output_dim=latent_dim, name="encoder_embedding")( encoder_inputs) encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_sequences=True, return_state=True, name="encoder_lstm")(enc_emb) encoder_states = [state_h, state_c] decoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,), name="decoder_inputs") dec_emb = layers.Embedding(input_dim=vocab_size, output_dim=latent_dim, name="decoder_embedding")( decoder_inputs) decoder_lstm_outputs, _, _ = layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_sequences=True, return_state=True, name="decoder_lstm")(dec_emb, initial_state=encoder_states) # Attention Layer attention = layers.Attention(name="attention_layer")([decoder_lstm_outputs, encoder_outputs]) decoder_combined_context = layers.Concatenate(axis=-1)([decoder_lstm_outputs, attention]) # Output decoder_outputs = layers.Dense(vocab_size, activation="softmax", name="output_dense")(decoder_combined_context) model = Model([encoder_inputs, decoder_inputs], decoder_outputs) model.compile(optimizer='adam', loss=masked_loss, metrics=['accuracy']) model.summary() decoder_target_data = np.zeros_like(decoder_input_data) decoder_target_data[:, :-1] = decoder_input_data[:, 1:] model.fit([encoder_input_data, decoder_input_data], np.expand_dims(decoder_target_data, -1), batch_size=32, epochs=15) model.save("SummarizerModel.keras") # with open("input_tokenizer.pkl", "wb") as f: # pickle.dump(input_tokenizer, f) # with open("target_tokenizer.pkl", "wb") as f: # pickle.dump(target_tokenizer, f) # encoder takes the most important information out of the input text, the decoder gets this text and try's to build a new text concluding the important information # and all this is happening because the tokenizer makes the input to numbers and then via embedding vectors are generated in the encoder which are representing the state of the "brain" and # the decoder takes this and trys formating a new text # Vectors are essential because tokenizer don't learn with semantic but embeddings do, for words with same semantic they receive same vectors e.g. [0.3, 0,31] word 1 [0.32, 0.34] word 2 # each word is a vector as long as the latent dimension that why it's used in the embeddings with tf.device('/GPU:0'): # /GPU:0 ist der Index für die erste GPU trainTextSummarizer() model = keras.models.load_model("SummarizerModel.keras", custom_objects={"masked_loss": masked_loss}) encoder_inputs = model.input[0] encoder_embedding = model.get_layer("encoder_embedding")(encoder_inputs) encoder_outputs, state_h_enc, state_c_enc = model.get_layer("encoder_lstm")(encoder_embedding) # LSTM Layers encoder_states = [state_h_enc, state_c_enc] encoder_model = keras.Model(encoder_inputs, [encoder_outputs, state_h_enc, state_c_enc]) # Decoder Model decoder_inputs = model.input[1] decoder_state_input_h = keras.Input(shape=(128,), name="decoder_state_input_h") decoder_state_input_c = keras.Input(shape=(128,), name="decoder_state_input_c") decoder_states_inputs = [decoder_state_input_h, decoder_state_input_c] decoder_hidden_state_input = Input(shape=(None, 128), name="decoder_hidden_input") dec_emb_layer = model.get_layer("decoder_embedding") dec_emb = dec_emb_layer(decoder_inputs) decoder_lstm = model.get_layer("decoder_lstm") decoder_lstm_outputs, state_h, state_c = decoder_lstm( dec_emb, initial_state=decoder_states_inputs ) attention_layer = model.get_layer("attention_layer") attention_output = attention_layer([decoder_lstm_outputs, decoder_hidden_state_input]) decoder_combined_context = Concatenate(axis=-1)([decoder_lstm_outputs, attention_output]) decoder_states = [state_h, state_c] decoder_dense = model.get_layer("output_dense") decoder_outputs = decoder_dense(decoder_combined_context) decoder_model = keras.Model( [decoder_inputs,decoder_hidden_state_input] + decoder_states_inputs, [decoder_outputs] + decoder_states, name="decoder_model" ) # grabs from the pretrained model, the layers and build two new separate models # during inference they need to separately def decode_sequence(input_text): # Tokenisierung der Eingabe input_ids = tokenizer(input_text, return_tensors="np", padding=True, truncation=True, max_length=512)["input_ids"] # Encoder Vorhersage encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = encoder_model.predict(input_ids) states_value = [state_h, state_c] # Decoder Startsequenz initialisieren target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1)) target_seq[0, 0] = tokenizer.convert_tokens_to_ids('<pad>') # Padding Token als Startwert stop_condition = False decoded_sentence = "" # Decoder Schleife while not stop_condition: output_tokens, h, c = decoder_model.predict([target_seq, encoder_outputs] + states_value) # Das nächste Wort bestimmen sampled_token_index = np.argmax(output_tokens[0, -1, :]) sampled_word = tokenizer.decode([sampled_token_index]) decoded_sentence += " " + sampled_word # Bedingung für das Stoppen der Sequenz if sampled_word.strip() == "</s>" or len(decoded_sentence.split()) > 50: stop_condition = True # Target Sequence für den nächsten Schritt vorbereiten target_seq = np.zeros((1, 1)) target_seq[0, 0] = sampled_token_index states_value = [h, c] return decoded_sentence.strip() test_text = ["Angela Merkel became Chancellor in 2011 after winning the election, just with 50% which is really crazy and cool"] summary = decode_sequence(test_text[0]) print(summary)
ChatGPT:

Dein Code ist im Großen und Ganzen gut strukturiert und solide aufgebaut, aber es gibt mehrere wichtige Punkte und Verbesserungsvorschläge, die du beachten solltest:

✅ Was funktioniert:

  • Die Verwendung des cnn_dailymail Datensatzes aus datasets.

  • Tokenisierung mit dem T5Tokenizer.

  • Training eines Encoder-Decoder-Modells mit Attention in Keras.

  • Eigene Verlustfunktion (masked_loss), die Padding ignoriert.

  • Inferenz mit getrennten Encoder- und Decoder-Modellen.

  • Dynamische Dekodierung mit einem Start-Token (hier <pad>) und Break-Condition.

⚠️ Wichtige Anmerkungen & Probleme:

1. T5Tokenizer ist nicht kompatibel mit Keras-Embedding + Decoder-Struktur

  • Du benutzt T5Tokenizer, der für Transformer gedacht ist, nicht für LSTM-basierte Seq2Seq-Modelle.

  • Die Tokenizer von HuggingFace generieren IDs für ein vokabularspezifisches Token-System, das nicht mit klassischen Keras-Embeddings kompatibel ist.

  • Du verwendest vocab_size = tokenizer.vocab_size – das kann >32.000 sein, was extrem viele Parameter für die Embedding- und Dense-Schichten erzeugt → Overkill für LSTM.

✅ Lösung:

  • Verwende stattdessen Tokenizer() von keras.preprocessing.text für beide Seiten (input_text, target_text) ODER nutze ein Transformer-Modell vollständig (z. B. T5ForConditionalGeneration).

2. Start-Token ist nicht richtig gesetzt

  • Du benutzt tokenizer.convert_tokens_to_ids('<pad>') als Start-Token → falsch.

  • Korrekt wäre z. B. tokenizer.convert_tokens_to_ids('<s>') oder sogar einen echten Starttoken, den du selbst einführst.

✅ Lösung:

  • Überlege dir eigene Tokens (<start>, <end>) mit Tokenizer(filters='') (wie in deinem auskommentierten Block), oder prüfe bei HuggingFace-Tokenizer die richtigen Start-/End-Tokens.

3. Decoder-Zielsequenz ist problematisch

python
decoder_target_data = np.zeros_like(decoder_input_data)
decoder_target_data[:, :-1] = decoder_input_data[:, 1:]

  • Das ist korrekt – aber du brauchst nicht die letzte Spalte 0 zu lassen, sondern solltest das Padding dort verwenden oder korrekt maskieren.

  • Achte darauf, dass das Target verschoben ist, aber auch korrekt maskiert wird.

4. Speicherproblemgefahr bei vielen Tokens (Großes Vokabular + Längere Texte)

  • CNN/DailyMail-Artikel sind lang. Bei padding='longest' kannst du leicht auf Sequenzlängen von 500–1000 kommen.

  • Dein Embedding → LSTM → Attention Stack auf diesen langen Sequenzen ist sehr speicherintensiv.

✅ Empfehlung:

  • Setze max_length=512 oder kleiner beim Tokenizer.

  • Oder arbeite nur mit einem Teil der Artikel per text[:300].

5. Tokenisierung in Inferenzzeit ist nicht exakt wie beim Training

python
tokenizer(input_text, return_tensors="np", ...)

  • Beim Training hast du padding="longest" verwendet, hier machst du padding=True + max_length=512.

  • Die Abweichung kann die Performance negativ beeinflussen.

✅ Lösung:

  • Verwende konsistente max_length und padding-Strategien (bspw. padding="max_length").

6. Wort-Zusammenfügen mit T5Tokenizer → tokenizer.decode([...])

  • Das kann bei Subword-Tokens (z. B. "##ung") unsaubere Wörter erzeugen.

✅ Lösung:

  • Verwende skip_special_tokens=True beim Decoding:

python
sampled_word = tokenizer.decode([sampled_token_index], skip_special_tokens=True)

🔧 Optionale Verbesserung:

  • Modularisiere deine trainTextSummarizer-Funktion (z. B. Encoder, Decoder, Tokenizer).

  • Nutze Callback-Mechanismen wie ModelCheckpoint oder EarlyStopping.

💡 Fazit:

Der Code funktioniert, aber du mischst ein Transformer-Tokenizer (T5Tokenizer) mit einer klassischen Seq2Seq-Architektur auf LSTM-Basis, was inkonsistent ist. Wenn du bei LSTM bleibst, nutze lieber Tokenizer() aus Keras. Oder du wechselst ganz auf Transformer-Architektur.

Möchtest du lieber:

  • bei LSTM + Keras bleiben (dann helfe ich dir, das Tokenizer-Problem zu lösen), oder

  • auf Huggingface/T5-basierte Transformer-Modelle umsteigen?

Du:
Nein es sollte auch mit dem Tokenizer gehen
ChatGPT:

Ja, dein Code ist grundsätzlich solide aufgebaut und verwendet den T5Tokenizer korrekt, allerdings gibt es einige kritische Punkte, die du beachten solltest, damit dein Modell wirklich gut funktioniert:

✅ Was gut ist:

  • Du verwendest T5Tokenizer konsistent für Eingabe und Zieltext.

  • Du hast einen sauberen Aufbau mit Attention-Mechanismus und Decoder-Loop zur Inferenz.

  • Dein masked_loss ist korrekt implementiert und hilft bei Padding-Tokens.

  • Du hast die Inferenz-Logik für die Zusammenfassung korrekt umgesetzt mit einem separaten Encoder- und Decoder-Modell.

⚠️ Was (noch) problematisch oder unklar ist:

1. T5Tokenizer ist nicht 1:1 kompatibel mit Embedding Layern:

Der T5Tokenizer produziert Token-IDs, die nicht alle zwischen 0 und vocab_size - 1 liegen, da einige davon Spezial-Tokens sind oder größer als vocab_size, weil sie Subword-Token enthalten. Beispiel: vocab_size = 32128, aber es kann Token-ID 32128 geben → Fehler im Embedding Layer.

✅ Lösung:
Du musst sicherstellen, dass input_dim im Embedding-Layer mindestens so groß ist wie die höchste Token-ID in deinen Daten, z. B.:

python
input_dim = max(np.max(encoder_input_data), np.max(decoder_input_data)) + 1

Oder du prüfst das so:

python
print("Max encoder token ID:", np.max(encoder_input_data))
print("Max decoder token ID:", np.max(decoder_input_data))
print("Tokenizer vocab size:", tokenizer.vocab_size)

2. Padding-Token statt Start-Token:

In der decode_sequence-Funktion initialisierst du die Decoder-Eingabe mit tokenizer.convert_tokens_to_ids('<pad>'). Das ist falsch, weil Padding kein Startsignal ist.

✅ Lösung:
Verwende stattdessen <pad> nur für Padding und z. B. <s> oder </s> (je nach Modelltraining) als Start-Token. In T5 ist <pad> korrekt, aber:

  • Der Starttoken wird nicht explizit benötigt, da T5 autoregressiv trainiert wurde und du einfach mit einem Dummy starten kannst (wie du es tust).

  • Aber du könntest z. B. tokenizer.pad_token_id oder explizit tokenizer.eos_token_id verwenden, wenn du </s> erwartest.

3. Decoder-Targets um eine Position versetzt?

Du hast das hier:

python
decoder_target_data = np.zeros_like(decoder_input_data)
decoder_target_data[:, :-1] = decoder_input_data[:, 1:]

Das ist korrekt – aber beachte: das letzte Token ist jetzt 0 (Padding). Willst du das? Oder wäre es besser, das tatsächliche End-Token </s> explizit zu setzen?

💡 Weitere Tipps

  • Speichere auch den Tokenizer mit tokenizer.save_pretrained("path"), damit du ihn beim Laden wieder korrekt rekonstruieren kannst.

  • Verwende evtl. EarlyStopping oder ModelCheckpoint, um Overfitting zu verhindern.

  • Nutze validation_split=0.1 in fit() für bessere Modellüberwachung.

Fazit:

✅ Ja, dein Code funktioniert prinzipiell mit dem Tokenizer, aber du musst unbedingt sicherstellen, dass:

  • die Embedding-Layer große genug für alle Token-IDs sind,

  • du auf Spezial-Tokens wie <pad> und </s> achtest,

  • und du die Decoder-Zielsequenz korrekt behandelst.

Möchtest du, dass ich dir helfe, die input_dim-Problematik im Code konkret zu lösen?

Du:
dec_emb = layers.Embedding(input_dim=vocab_size, output_dim=latent_dim, name="decoder_embedding")( ich mach halt als input_dim die vocab size
ChatGPT:

Das ist grundsätzlich korrekt gedacht, aber bei Verwendung von T5Tokenizer nicht immer ausreichend. Warum?

⚠️ Problem: T5Tokenizer kann Token-IDs > tokenizer.vocab_size zurückgeben

python
tokenizer.vocab_size  # z. B. 32100

Wenn du tokenizer.encode("Text", return_tensors="np") oder batch_encode_plus(...) verwendest, kann es vorkommen, dass der Tokenizer IDs zurückgibt, die größer als vocab_size - 1 sind. Das passiert insbesondere bei bestimmten PreTokenized Eingaben oder durch unbekannte Tokens, da T5Tokenizer SentencePiece verwendet und mit IDs außerhalb des Standardvokabulars arbeiten kann.

✅ Wie du es sicher richtig machst:

Option 1: Automatisch höchste ID bestimmen

Ermittle die höchste vorkommende Token-ID in deinen Daten und setze input_dim entsprechend:

python
max_id = max(np.max(encoder_input_data), np.max(decoder_input_data))
dec_emb = layers.Embedding(input_dim=max_id + 1, output_dim=latent_dim, name="decoder_embedding")(...)

Option 2: Sicherheit mit Puffer:

Falls du nicht vortrainierte Embeddings nutzt, kannst du vocab_size + 100 als Puffer verwenden (nicht optimal, aber pragmatisch):

python
dec_emb = layers.Embedding(input_dim=tokenizer.vocab_size + 100, output_dim=latent_dim, name="decoder_embedding")(...)

🔍 Prüfen, ob das Problem bei dir existiert:

Mach einmal Folgendes vor dem Training:

python
print("Max encoder ID:", np.max(encoder_input_data))
print("Max decoder ID:", np.max(decoder_input_data))
print("Vocab size from tokenizer:", tokenizer.vocab_size)

Wenn max decoder ID > vocab_size - 1, dann wird dein Embedding-Input fehlschlagen – das passiert zur Laufzeit mit:

indices[xx] >= input_dim → Embedding layer kann den Token nicht einbetten.

Fazit:

Ja, input_dim=vocab_size reicht nur dann, wenn wirklich keine Token-ID größer als vocab_size - 1 in deinem Daten vorkommt.

Möchtest du, dass ich dir einen kleinen Code-Snippet schreibe, der diese Prüfung automatisch in dein Training integriert?

Du:
import keras import numpy as np from keras.preprocessing.text import Tokenizer from keras import Input, Model, layers from datasets import load_dataset import tensorflow as tf from keras_preprocessing.sequence import pad_sequences import pickle from transformers import T5Tokenizer from keras.layers import Attention, Concatenate dataset = load_dataset("abisee/cnn_dailymail", "3.0.0") # # input_text = [ # "Angela Merkel wurde 2011 Bundeskanzlerin, nachdem sie die Wahl gewonnen hatte", # "Bayer hat vorgestern am Abend 5:3 gegen Dortmund gewonnen, war super das Spiel", # "Die deutsche Wirtschaft wächst trotz der internationalen Unsicherheiten stetig weiter.", # "Tesla hat kürzlich sein neues Elektroauto-Modell vorgestellt, das eine Reichweite von über 600 Kilometern bietet." # ] # # target_text = [ # "Angela Merkel wurde 2011 Bundeskanzlerin", # "Bayern gewann 5:3 gegen Dortmund", # "Deutsche Wirtschaft wächst trotz Unsicherheiten", # "Tesla stellt neues Elektroauto vor" # ] input_text = dataset['train']['article'][:10000] # Artikel aus dem Datensatz target_text = dataset['train']['highlights'][:10000] # #Tokenizer preparation # input_tokenizer = Tokenizer() # input_tokenizer.fit_on_texts(input_text) # formats the text into numbers like this TextVectorization # input_sequences = input_tokenizer.texts_to_sequences(input_text) # # start_token = '<start>' # end_token = '<end>' # target_text_with_tokens = [start_token + " " + text + " " + end_token for text in target_text] # OWN TOKENIZER # # target_tokenizer = Tokenizer(filters='',num_words=20000) # target_tokenizer.fit_on_texts(target_text_with_tokens) # target_sequences = target_tokenizer.texts_to_sequences(target_text_with_tokens) tokenizer = T5Tokenizer.from_pretrained("t5-small") input_encodings = tokenizer(input_text, padding="longest", truncation=True, return_tensors="np") target_encodings = tokenizer(target_text, padding="longest", truncation=True, return_tensors="np") encoder_input_data = input_encodings["input_ids"] decoder_input_data = target_encodings["input_ids"] vocab_size = tokenizer.vocab_size loss_fn = tf.keras.losses.SparseCategoricalCrossentropy(from_logits=False, reduction='none') def masked_loss(y_true, y_pred): loss = loss_fn(y_true, y_pred) mask = tf.cast(tf.not_equal(y_true, 0), dtype=loss.dtype) mask = tf.expand_dims(mask, axis=-1) loss *= mask return tf.reduce_sum(loss) / tf.reduce_sum(mask) def trainTextSummarizer(): # Data preparation # max_encoder_seq_length = max(len(seq) for seq in input_sequences) # declares the max len for input and target # max_decoder_seq_length = max(len(seq) for seq in target_sequences) # # encoder_input_data = pad_sequences(input_sequences, maxlen=max_encoder_seq_length, # padding="post") # secures that all sequences have the same length if # # they are too short, # # padding is comming # decoder_input_data = pad_sequences(target_sequences, maxlen=max_decoder_seq_length, # padding="post") # parameter # num_encoder_tokens = len(input_tokenizer.word_index) + 1 # number of unique words plus 1 for the padding # num_decoder_tokens = len(target_tokenizer.word_index) + 1 # same here latent_dim = 128 # neuron count input_dim = max(np.max(encoder_input_data), np.max(decoder_input_data)) + 1 # encoder # encoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,)) # Input layer for the encoder with no declared shape # enc_emb = layers.Embedding(num_encoder_tokens, latent_dim)( # encoder_inputs) # changes every word from input to a vector with strict dimension the latent dimension (neurons) # # encoder_outputs, state_h, state_c = layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_state=True)(enc_emb) # encoder_states = [state_h, state_c] # brain status is returned, the most important features of the text # # # decoder # decoder_inputs = Input(shape=(None,)) # Input layer for the decoder # dec_emb = layers.Embedding(num_decoder_tokens, latent_dim)( # decoder_inputs) # changes every word from input to a vector with strict dimension the latent dimension (neurons) # # decoder_outputs, _, _ =layers.LSTM(latent_dim, return_sequences=True, return_state=True)(dec_emb, # initial_state=encoder_states) # brain status is returned (Not real) # decoder_outputs =layers.Dense(num_decoder_tokens, activation="softmax")(decoder_outputs) #
